title: How to Melt Hard Wax Beans

steps.headline: Pour the wax beans into the inner warming chamber.
steps.description: Simply open the lid on your wax warmer and pour the beans into the inner chamber. Many warmers have a fill line marked on the inner chamber—don't add beans beyond this line. If there isn't a fill line, don't fill the chamber more than two-thirds full. Follow the package instructions on your hard wax beans for guidance on how much you'll need to use. As a rough estimate, it usually takes about 2.5 oz (71 g) of beans to wax your underarms. Wax warmers are the easiest and safest way to melt hard wax beans. They're small, plug-in appliances that heat the wax evenly and maintain the proper temperature well. You can get a basic wax warmer for around $40 USD at beauty supply retailers or online, along with bags of hard wax beans and wooden applicator sticks.

steps.headline: Set the warmer to the recommended warming setting.
steps.description: Basic warmers usually have dials with low, medium, and high settings, but your particular model may have other warming settings. Use the instructions for your warmer and those on your package of beans to determine the proper warming setting. If you can't find specific guidance, set the warmer to medium. This is one of the main advantages of using a wax warmer—you can just “set it and forget it!”

steps.headline: Check the wax temperature after about 30 minutes.
steps.description: Warming times will vary based on your model and the recommended heat setting, so check your product instructions. Typically, though, it takes about 30-45 minutes to melt and heat hard wax beans to the right temperature. If there is a downside to using a wax warmer, it's that it takes a bit longer than using a microwave or a double boiler on the stovetop. However, this slow, even warming process is the best way to melt wax for hair removal. Unless your warmer model advises otherwise, you don't need to worry about stirring the wax as it melts.

steps.headline: Use the warmer to maintain a temperature between 125–160 °F (52–71 °C).
steps.description: If your warmer doesn't have a built-in temperature gauge, lift the lid and insert a heat-safe thermometer into the wax (without touching the bottom of the container). If the wax is within the ideal range, turn the warmer to its lowest setting. This way, the wax will remain in the ideal temperature range while you do your waxing. Do not use the wax if the temperature is above 165 °F (74 °C). Turn the warmer off, then turn it back to the lowest setting when your thermometer reads 160 °F (71 °C) or below. Wax that's above the ideal temperature range can cause burns; wax that's below the range will be too congealed and clumpy to apply in a smooth, thick layer over your skin.

methods.name: Heating Wax Beans on the Stove

steps.headline: Grab a heat-resistant bowl that nestles nicely on top of a pot or saucepan.
steps.description: Making your own stovetop double boiler is easy. You just need to find a bowl that will sit on top of a pot or saucepan like an inverted lid. The bottom of the bowl shouldn't reach down more than one-third of the way into the pot. Try a metal or heat-resistant glass mixing bowl—don't use plastic! When in place, the bowl should create a seal all the way around the rim of the pot or saucepan. This way, the steam won't be able to escape.

steps.headline: Add about 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm) of water to the saucepan.
steps.description: You don't need much water to create an effective double boiler, since trapped steam will do all the work. Add at least 1 in (2.5 cm) of water so it doesn't boil away completely, but don't fill the pot more than halfway full. You don't want the bottom of the bowl to touch the water in the pot. Ideally, there should be at least 1 in (2.5 cm) of space between them.

steps.headline: Bring the water to a boil, then reduce it to a low simmer.
steps.description: Turn your stove onto medium or high heat, and put a lid on your pot if you want it to boil faster (don't use the bowl yet). When the water is bubbling rapidly, turn the heat down to a very low setting—just enough to maintain a simmer. At a simmer, the water should be just barely bubbling.

steps.headline: Pour the beans into the bowl, then nestle it on the pot.
steps.description: Use the directions on the bag of hard wax beans to get an idea of how much you need. For example, you'll probably need about 1.25 oz (35 g) of beans to wax both your upper lip and your eyebrows. Leave enough room in the bowl so that you'll be able to easily stir the wax mixture without causing it to spill over the sides.

steps.headline: Stir the wax frequently with a spatula or wooden spoon.
steps.description: A double boiler provides more gentle, even heating than what you'd get by melting the beans right in the pot. However, the wax beans will still heat and melt unevenly, so give them a good stir every minute or so. Your best stirring options are a silicone spatula, a wooden spoon, or one of the wax applicator sticks you'll be using (they look like Popsicle sticks). If your bowl starts to shake or rattle, too much steam is building up beneath it. Turn down the heat even more. Don't lift off the bowl, or your hands and face may get blasted by scalding hot steam. Remove the pot from the heat for a few minutes if necessary.

steps.headline: Turn off the heat when your thermometer reads 150 °F (66 °C).
steps.description: Stick a heat-resistant thermometer into the melted wax, making sure not to touch the bottom or sides of the bowl. The wax temperature will continue to rise for a few minutes after you turn off the heat, so don't let it get all the way up to 160 °F (71 °C), or it may be too hot when you try to apply it. The ideal temperature range for hard wax used on your body is 125–160 °F (52–71 °C). Wax that's over 165 °F (74 °C) can cause burns. Leave the wax in the bowl, and leave the bowl on top of the pot. The residual heat will help keep it above 125 °F (52 °C) longer. If the wax starts to get too goopy to apply easily, turn the heat back on to low until the wax reaches 150 °F (66 °C) again.

steps.headline: Pour the wax beans into a microwave-safe glass or bowl.
steps.description: A heat-resistant glass mixing bowl is probably your best option here. Make sure the bowl is large enough so that you don't have to fill it more than halfway with hard wax beans. Use your bean package for guidance on how much to use. You'll probably need around 24 oz (680 g) to wax one of your legs.

steps.headline: Set your microwave power setting to 20 percent.
steps.description: At full power, the microwave will melt the wax unevenly, causing some spots to be dangerously hot while others aren't melted at all. Setting your microwave lower will help to heat the wax more slowly and evenly. Superheated wax could spontaneously erupt when you go to stir it, which could cause serious burns. Heat wax in the microwave very slowly and very carefully. Check your user's manual for guidance on reducing the power level on your microwave.

steps.headline: Heat the wax for 10 seconds, then stir it.
steps.description: After only 10 seconds, the wax beans will look like they haven't melted at all. However, once you begin to stir them, you'll see that they're beginning to lose their shape. Stirring helps to ensure that the wax beans are heating and melting evenly, so don't skip this step! Use an oven mitt or towel to grab the bowl—it may be very hot! Use a silicone spatula, wooden spoon, or wooden wax applicator stick to stir the wax.

steps.headline: Repeat the process in 10-second increments until the wax is melted.
steps.description: Pop the bowl back into the microwave for 10 more seconds, and make sure it's still set at 20% power. Stir the bowl again. Once the wax seems evenly melted after stirring, use a heat-resistant thermometer to check it—it should be between 125–160 °F (52–71 °C) for use on your body. Do not use the wax if it is over 165 °F (74 °C), or you may burn your skin. Melting times vary based on your microwave and the amount of beans you're melting, but it probably won't take more than 6 rounds of 10-second heating increments.

steps.headline: Reheat the wax as needed when it starts to congeal.
steps.description: While a microwave is the quickest way to melt hard wax beans, it provides little residual heat to keep them at the ideal temperature. Within a few minutes, the wax will drop below 125 °F (52 °C) and start to get too clumpy to apply to your skin. When this happens, pop it back into the microwave for 10-second increments as before. Make sure the microwave is still set at 20% power.
